clusters.title: Pregnant women in England at ‘growing risk’ of serious injury in childbirth

items.title: Pregnant women in England at ‘growing risk’ of serious injury in childbirth
items.standfirst: NHS figures show number of mothers sustaining third- or fourth-degree perineal tear has increased by 16% since 2020Pregnant women in England are at growing risk of suffering a serious injury while giving birth, NHS figures reveal.The number of mothers sustaining a third- or fourth-degree perineal tear while delivering their baby has risen from 25 in 1,000 in June 2020 to 29 in 1,000 in June this year – a 16% increase. Continue reading...
items.content: NHS figures show number of mothers sustaining third- or fourth-degree perineal tear has increased by 16% since 2020Pregnant women in England are at growing risk of suffering a serious injury while giving birth, NHS figures reveal.The number of mothers sustaining a third- or fourth-degree perineal tear while delivering their baby has risen from 25 in 1,000 in June 2020 to 29 in 1,000 in June this year – a 16% increase. Continue reading...

ai_summary: NHS data shows a 16% increase in third or fourth-degree perineal tears since 2020.
In June 2020, 25 out of 1,000 mothers experienced these tears; in June 2024, it was 29.
These injuries are considered serious and can cause significant long-term health issues.
The rise in injuries highlights concerns about maternity care quality in England.
The NHS is facing increasing pressure to address these rising injury rates.

clusters.title: NHS medical negligence liabilities hit £60bn amid surge in maternity payouts
clusters.neutral_headline: NHS Medical Negligence Liabilities Reach Sixty Billion Pounds

items.title: NHS medical negligence liabilities hit £60bn amid surge in maternity payouts
items.standfirst: Audit finds average childbirth injury case costs more than £11m to settle as watchdog urges stronger safety measuresThe NHS’s total liabilities for medical negligence have hit £60bn, driven by a jump in childbirth injury cases that cost more than £11m each on average to settle.The total sum of money the health service in England may have to pay out to settle lawsuits for mistakes by staff has quadrupled from £14.4bn in 2006-07, amid more claims and rising legal costs.the bill for negligence is expected to reach £4.1bn in 2029-30the number of cases settled has more than doubled from 5,625 in 2006-07 to 13,329 in 2024-25the total number of settlements has fallen in 11 specialties but risen in six others Continue reading...
items.content: Audit finds average childbirth injury case costs more than £11m to settle as watchdog urges stronger safety measuresThe NHS’s total liabilities for medical negligence have hit £60bn, driven by a jump in childbirth injury cases that cost more than £11m each on average to settle.The total sum of money the health service in England may have to pay out to settle lawsuits for mistakes by staff has quadrupled from £14.4bn in 2006-07, amid more claims and rising legal costs.the bill for negligence is expected to reach £4.1bn in 2029-30the number of cases settled has more than doubled from 5,625 in 2006-07 to 13,329 in 2024-25the total number of settlements has fallen in 11 specialties but risen in six others Continue reading...

ai_summary: The NHS's total liabilities for medical negligence have reached sixty billion pounds.
Childbirth injury cases are a major driver, costing over eleven million pounds each.
The total sum for settling lawsuits has quadrupled since 2006-07.
Negligence costs are projected to reach four point one billion pounds by 2029-30.
The number of settled cases has more than doubled since 2006-07.

clusters.title: Thousands in UK take legal action against Johnson & Johnson over alleged talc cancer link
clusters.neutral_headline: Thousands in UK take legal action against Johnson & Johnson over alleged talc cancer link

items.title: Thousands in UK take legal action against Johnson & Johnson over alleged talc cancer link
items.standfirst: High court claim says company knowingly sold product containing asbestos and ‘concealed’ risk to public‘When I was a child, everyone used it’: woman blames Johnson & Johnson talc for her cancerThousands of people are taking legal action against the US pharmaceutical company Johnson & Johnson, claiming it knowingly sold baby powder containing asbestos-contaminated talc in the UK.About 3,000 people have alleged that they or a family member developed forms of ovarian cancer or mesothelioma from using Johnson’s Baby Powder, and are seeking damages at the high court in London. Continue reading...
items.content: High court claim says company knowingly sold product containing asbestos and ‘concealed’ risk to public‘When I was a child, everyone used it’: woman blames Johnson & Johnson talc for her cancerThousands of people are taking legal action against the US pharmaceutical company Johnson & Johnson, claiming it knowingly sold baby powder containing asbestos-contaminated talc in the UK.About 3,000 people have alleged that they or a family member developed forms of ovarian cancer or mesothelioma from using Johnson’s Baby Powder, and are seeking damages at the high court in London. Continue reading...

items.title: ‘When I was a child, everyone used it’: woman blames Johnson & Johnson talc for her cancer
items.standfirst: Sue Rizzello is among thousands in UK suing the firm, which denies selling baby powder containing asbestosThousands in UK take legal action against Johnson & Johnson over alleged talc cancer linkIt was Sue Rizzello’s husband who persuaded her to see a doctor, concerned about the bloating in her abdomen that was making her more and more uncomfortable. Rizzello, then in her late 40s, had assumed it was menopausal weight gain, but agreed to go to her GP. “A smart locum said: ‘There’s something wrong here,’ and sent me for a blood test … And that saved my life.”It was the worst news: Rizzello had stage 3 ovarian cancer that had begun to spread. She would need to begin chemotherapy immediately and prepare for the complete removal of her uterus, ovaries, fallopian tubes and omentum, a procedure that would put her into immediate menopause. Continue reading...
items.content: Sue Rizzello is among thousands in UK suing the firm, which denies selling baby powder containing asbestosThousands in UK take legal action against Johnson & Johnson over alleged talc cancer linkIt was Sue Rizzello’s husband who persuaded her to see a doctor, concerned about the bloating in her abdomen that was making her more and more uncomfortable. Rizzello, then in her late 40s, had assumed it was menopausal weight gain, but agreed to go to her GP. “A smart locum said: ‘There’s something wrong here,’ and sent me for a blood test … And that saved my life.”It was the worst news: Rizzello had stage 3 ovarian cancer that had begun to spread. She would need to begin chemotherapy immediately and prepare for the complete removal of her uterus, ovaries, fallopian tubes and omentum, a procedure that would put her into immediate menopause. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Thousands of people are suing Johnson & Johnson over alleged asbestos-contaminated talc.
Claimants allege the company knowingly sold baby powder containing asbestos.
Around 3,000 people claim they or family members developed cancer from the powder.
They are seeking damages in the high court in London.
One woman blames Johnson & Johnson talc for her ovarian cancer diagnosis.

clusters.title: Night owls versus early birds: who is superior according to science?
clusters.neutral_headline: Night owls versus early birds: who is superior according to science?

items.title: Night owls versus early birds: who is superior according to science?
items.standfirst: And is it actually possible for your body clock to change? Am I really turning into an early bird or have I just been forced into a child-dictated schedule?We all know that early birds get the worm. But who wants a worm? Not me. For most of my life I have identified as a night owl, clambering out of bed as late as possible and not so much seizing but reluctantly easing into the day.US work culture is not really optimal for night owls. Rather, it favours CEOs who get up at 4am and run a marathon while the rest of us hit the snooze button. Still, I always consoled myself with the idea that night owls are actually more intelligent and creative than their early bird counterparts. Franz Kafka and Thomas Wolfe wrote at bedtime; Bob Dylan recorded at night. Even scientific studies indicated it was true. Continue reading...
items.content: And is it actually possible for your body clock to change? Am I really turning into an early bird or have I just been forced into a child-dictated schedule?We all know that early birds get the worm. But who wants a worm? Not me. For most of my life I have identified as a night owl, clambering out of bed as late as possible and not so much seizing but reluctantly easing into the day.US work culture is not really optimal for night owls. Rather, it favours CEOs who get up at 4am and run a marathon while the rest of us hit the snooze button. Still, I always consoled myself with the idea that night owls are actually more intelligent and creative than their early bird counterparts. Franz Kafka and Thomas Wolfe wrote at bedtime; Bob Dylan recorded at night. Even scientific studies indicated it was true. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article explores the differences between night owls and early birds.
It questions whether body clocks can change and if night owls are superior.
The author identifies as a night owl and dislikes early mornings.
US work culture is not optimal for night owls, favoring early risers.
The article mentions scientific studies suggesting night owls may be more creative.

clusters.title: Why is ‘chronic’ lyme disease so controversial? – podcast
clusters.neutral_headline: Why is ‘chronic’ lyme disease so controversial? – podcast

items.title: Why is ‘chronic’ lyme disease so controversial? – podcast
items.standfirst: Celebrities including Bella Hadid, Justin Bieber and Miranda Hart have talked about their years-long struggles with the effects of Lyme disease, but despite rising rates and better awareness, the illness remains poorly understood. To understand more about how the illness can impact people over the long term, Madeleine Finlay hears from the Guardian’s Patrick Barkham about his daughter Milly’s experience, and from Prof John Aucott, director of the Johns Hopkins Lyme Disease Research Center, and associate professor of medicine at Johns Hopkins UniversityAs my daughter got sicker and sicker, our quest for answers dragged on. How did we all miss the bacteria taking over her body?Support the Guardian Continue reading...
items.content: Celebrities including Bella Hadid, Justin Bieber and Miranda Hart have talked about their years-long struggles with the effects of Lyme disease, but despite rising rates and better awareness, the illness remains poorly understood. To understand more about how the illness can impact people over the long term, Madeleine Finlay hears from the Guardian’s Patrick Barkham about his daughter Milly’s experience, and from Prof John Aucott, director of the Johns Hopkins Lyme Disease Research Center, and associate professor of medicine at Johns Hopkins UniversityAs my daughter got sicker and sicker, our quest for answers dragged on. How did we all miss the bacteria taking over her body?Support the Guardian Continue reading...

ai_summary: The podcast explores the controversy surrounding chronic Lyme disease.

clusters.title: PPE firm linked to Michelle Mone misses deadline to repay £122m

items.title: PPE firm linked to Michelle Mone misses deadline to repay £122m
items.standfirst: Firm was ordered by high court to return sum paid by DHSC for unusable surgical gowns by 4pm on WednesdayA company linked to the former Conservative peer Michelle Mone has failed to pay the government any of the £122m ordered by a high court judgment for supplying unusable personal protective equipment during the Covid pandemic.Mrs Justice Cockerill ruled that PPE Medpro must, by a deadline of 4pm on 15 October, return the money it was paid by the Department of Health and Social Care for 25m sterile surgical gowns under a contract awarded in June 2020. Continue reading...
items.content: Firm was ordered by high court to return sum paid by DHSC for unusable surgical gowns by 4pm on WednesdayA company linked to the former Conservative peer Michelle Mone has failed to pay the government any of the £122m ordered by a high court judgment for supplying unusable personal protective equipment during the Covid pandemic.Mrs Justice Cockerill ruled that PPE Medpro must, by a deadline of 4pm on 15 October, return the money it was paid by the Department of Health and Social Care for 25m sterile surgical gowns under a contract awarded in June 2020. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A firm linked to Michelle Mone missed a deadline to repay £122 million.

The high court ordered PPE Medpro to return the funds.
The deadline for repayment was 4 pm on October 15th.
The company failed to meet the court-ordered repayment.

clusters.title: Who’s to blame for the NHS’s blame culture? | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Who’s to blame for the NHS’s blame culture? | Letters

items.title: Who’s to blame for the NHS’s blame culture? | Letters
items.standfirst: Dr David Zigmond, Dr Richard Sloan, Dr Eric Watts and Dr Ian Freeman respond to an article by the former health secretary Jeremy HuntJeremy Hunt’s article (Here’s the direct effect of our NHS blame culture: babies die. Tragedy after tragedy, it can’t go on, 9 October) will be welcome to many, especially those healthcare professionals who have had to endure the intimidating mistrust and adversarial working culture he describes.What is missing from his account is the seminal role of government’s NHS reforms in creating these problems. In particular, the creation, then proliferation, of commercialised and competing autarkic NHS trusts and outside providers over many years. This has generated a growing culture of corporate defensiveness and reputation anxiety. Within such conditions, practitioners then adapt to behave much like employees in large commercial organisations – they must show compliance, “loyalty”, conformity and seamless performance, albeit speciously. Continue reading...
items.content: Dr David Zigmond, Dr Richard Sloan, Dr Eric Watts and Dr Ian Freeman respond to an article by the former health secretary Jeremy HuntJeremy Hunt’s article (Here’s the direct effect of our NHS blame culture: babies die. Tragedy after tragedy, it can’t go on, 9 October) will be welcome to many, especially those healthcare professionals who have had to endure the intimidating mistrust and adversarial working culture he describes.What is missing from his account is the seminal role of government’s NHS reforms in creating these problems. In particular, the creation, then proliferation, of commercialised and competing autarkic NHS trusts and outside providers over many years. This has generated a growing culture of corporate defensiveness and reputation anxiety. Within such conditions, practitioners then adapt to behave much like employees in large commercial organisations – they must show compliance, “loyalty”, conformity and seamless performance, albeit speciously. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article discusses the NHS's blame culture.
It responds to an article by former health secretary Jeremy Hunt.
The letters highlight the role of government reforms.
They criticize the creation of competing NHS trusts.
The reforms are seen as contributing to corporate defensiveness.

clusters.title: Don’t give in to big pharma on drug pricing | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Drug Pricing Debate: UK NHS and Pharmaceutical Industry Perspectives

items.title: Don’t give in to big pharma on drug pricing | Letters
items.standfirst: Drug manufacturers may lament the UK’s drug prices, writes Simon Dixon, but the NHS should celebrate themWhile the chief executive of Eli Lilly may lament the UK’s drug prices (UK is ‘worst country in Europe’ for drug prices, says Mounjaro maker, 24 September), the NHS should celebrate them. The system put in place for evaluating the cost-effectiveness of new drugs is respected the world over and is successful in applying the principle that funding a new product should not damage the NHS as a whole. This principle of cost-effectiveness has led to widespread price reductions for the NHS that have allowed the service as a whole to benefit.The chief executive of Eli Lilly links the recent pausing or cancelling of pharmaceutical industry investments in the UK to drug pricing here, when these are down to the drug companies’ desperation to kowtow to Donald Trump. Continue reading...
items.content: Drug manufacturers may lament the UK’s drug prices, writes Simon Dixon, but the NHS should celebrate themWhile the chief executive of Eli Lilly may lament the UK’s drug prices (UK is ‘worst country in Europe’ for drug prices, says Mounjaro maker, 24 September), the NHS should celebrate them. The system put in place for evaluating the cost-effectiveness of new drugs is respected the world over and is successful in applying the principle that funding a new product should not damage the NHS as a whole. This principle of cost-effectiveness has led to widespread price reductions for the NHS that have allowed the service as a whole to benefit.The chief executive of Eli Lilly links the recent pausing or cancelling of pharmaceutical industry investments in the UK to drug pricing here, when these are down to the drug companies’ desperation to kowtow to Donald Trump. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The NHS should celebrate the UK's drug prices, which are cost-effective and benefit the service.
Eli Lilly's CEO links investment pauses to UK drug pricing, but this is due to other factors.
The UK's system for evaluating drug cost-effectiveness is respected globally.
Price reductions have allowed the NHS to benefit overall.
Drug companies are allegedly desperate to appease Donald Trump.

clusters.title: ‘Alarming rise’ in mental health stigma in England, research shows
clusters.neutral_headline: Mental Health Stigma in England Shows Alarming Rise

items.title: ‘Alarming rise’ in mental health stigma in England, research shows
items.standfirst: One in 10 people unwilling to live next to someone who has been mentally ill even if they have recovered, Mind reportsThe number of people in England who are frightened of living near people with mental health problems has nearly doubled to one in seven, which experts warn reflects an “alarming rise in stigma”.Even if the mentally ill person had recovered, one in 10 people said they would be unwilling to live next to them, according to new research from the mental health charity Mind. Continue reading...
items.content: One in 10 people unwilling to live next to someone who has been mentally ill even if they have recovered, Mind reportsThe number of people in England who are frightened of living near people with mental health problems has nearly doubled to one in seven, which experts warn reflects an “alarming rise in stigma”.Even if the mentally ill person had recovered, one in 10 people said they would be unwilling to live next to them, according to new research from the mental health charity Mind. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Research indicates an alarming rise in mental health stigma in England.
Nearly one in seven people are frightened of living near those with mental illness.
One in ten people would not live near a recovered person with mental illness.
The research comes from the mental health charity Mind.
The increase in stigma is a significant concern for experts.

ai_summary: Almost 70% of US adults would be considered obese under a new definition.
The traditional BMI-based definition of obesity is often debated.
The new definition is proposed by medical experts.
The new definition has not yet been adopted.
The traditional definition does not differentiate between fat and muscle.

clusters.title: Controversial UK oil field publishes full scale of climate impact
clusters.neutral_headline: Controversial UK oil field publishes full scale of climate impact: The impact from the Rosebank oil field is estimated at nearly 250 million tonnes of planet warming CO2

ai_summary: The Rosebank oil field's climate impact is estimated at nearly 250 million tonnes of CO2.
The BBC Science article focuses on the environmental impact of the oil field.
The article highlights the controversy surrounding the oil field's operations.
The full scale of the climate impact has been published.
The CO2 emissions contribute to global warming.
